physDesc.p: Three pages typewritten in black ink. Address given for H. D. in the top left corner of the first page: Mrs. Richard Aldington c/o Manager, Lloyd’s Bank, 67 Kingsway, London W.C.2. England. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: A delightful little Christmas card came from you this morning. I am so glad to get it. But how far ahead of me you have got! It never occurred to me to send my European Christmas cards until this week, and now you make me fear that mine to you will come after the day, which, although it may have become a habit, is nevertheless regrettable.

My dear, your "Heliodora" is superb! I have not really been able to read it yet with the thoroughness that I want to, slim volume though it is, because I only finished the corrections of my "Keats" yesterday, and nobody knows what a grind that book has been, but I have read enough of "Heliodora" to realize that it is no fall from "Hymen," on the contrary, it is a magnificent thing. Mr. Greenslet tells me what Boni & Liveright are to publish a collected edition of your books, for which I am heartily thankful, although I wish it were not Boni & Liveright but Houghton Mifflin. But Houghton Mifflin are so slow to jump when they should. It will be a comfort to have your "Sea Garden" in print again. People are always asking me where they can get it. I enc

I am enclosing a little card which the publishers have printed for my book, which, between us, we did not get out for Christmas. It means that my real Christmas present to you, the book itself, will follow as soon as it is issued.

I also enclose a draft for the last two royalty payments on the surviving "Imagist Poets." The account is as follows: 3 Imagist Poets at .671/2 2.03 10 " " 1916 at .67-1/2 6.75 11 " " 1917 " " 7.43 1/6 of 16.21 is $2.70 This represents both the February 1924 and the August 1924 payments, which I am sending together as they are both so small. The two first anthologies went out of print with the August statement, and there are only six copies of the "1917" left, so we shall soon have done with them altogether.

I have not heard a word from Winifred for ever so long. It is entirely my fault. She wrote and told me that she was unable to do the article on me as she had planned, and what should she do with the manuscript I sent her. And I have never answered her, owing entirely to pressure of work. I have been grinding at this book so steadily that I have not been able to keep up with my mail at all. Four years and two months I have been at it, and I am so weary to the core, but I have a sort of colt-let-out-in-a-meadow kind of feeling now that it is all over.

I am going to England – think of it, after eleven years! We are sailing on the Berengaria for Southampton on April fifteenth, and I expect to give some lectures and readings while I am there. I have quite a number booked. We shall stay until about the middle of July and then sail for home again without going on to the continent at all. Some other time I hope to go to Italy again, but my initial trip, after all these many operations of mine, will not take me beyond England. I do hope you will manage to be in London while we are there. It seems so long since we have met, and I am so anxious to see you again.

I hope you will like my book. I shall be dreadfully disappointed if you do not, but I hope you will like still better the poetry volume which I expect to bring out a year from now. After all, poetry is my real job.

What happened to your book of essays on Greek subjects, the one which I read the manuscript of and spoke to Ferris Greenslet about? Is that coming out with Boni & Liveright’s collected edition or not? There are so many people I should like to give it to.

Drop us a line, dear Hilda, and tell us your news. I got a little breath of you from Louis Untermeyer in the Summer, but it seems a long time since I have heard from you yourself, and that made the Christmas card particularly welcome.
Mrs. Russell sends her love, and so do I, both to you and your mother, if she is with you.
